user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_destroy:
```c
void
MHD_pool_destroy (struct MemoryPool *pool)
{
  if (NULL == pool)
    return;

  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
  _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (pool->memory, pool->size);
  if (! pool->is_mmap)
    free (pool->memory);
  else
#if defined(MAP_ANONYMOUS) && ! defined(_WIN32)
    munmap (pool->memory,
            pool->size);
#elif defined(_WIN32)
    VirtualFree (pool->memory,
                 0,
                 MEM_RELEASE);
#else
    abort ();
#endif
  free (pool);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment only performs an integer comparison via mhd_assert(pool->end >= pool->pos) and does not call any <string.h> functions (memcpy, memset, strcpy, etc.). Rule 21.17 targets use of string handling functions that can access beyond object bounds; this line does not use them. (A violating scenario would be, for example, calling memcpy(pool->memory + pool->pos, src, pool->size) without ensuring the source and destination buffers are large enough.)
